channel.title: New Computer: 32 or 64 bit?
channel.description:
I'm buying a new computer next month for my Open University course in OOP Java. I have £265 (+ maybe an extra £10 - £15), but anyway...
I looked on PC world and I can get a 3GB RAM laptop/320GB HDD, with a decent graphics card inside my budget, but it's 64 bit.
I know that 64 bit is just more CPU power and uses the full amount of RAM as opposed to a 32 bit operating system only using 2/3rds of the maximum capacity RAM... [i]but[/i] I also heard that 64 bit is only worth it if you have 4GB+ RAM...
And also, a 64 bit system potentially uses more resources anyway, so could in effect decrease performance.
64 bit is becoming ever so more popular though.
So, I was wondering what your opinion on the matter is? 32 or 64?
Thanks for reading.

item.title: New Computer: 32 or 64 bit?
item.dc:creator: @krackkid Krackkid
item.description:
@krackkid wrote:

Mendorphins go on the IRC.

Read full topic

item.title: New Computer: 32 or 64 bit?
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

Moparisthebest:

I don’t really think you can buy a new CPU that only supports 32-bit anymore, so your question is to go with a 64-bit OS or a 32-bit OS? A 64-bit one can use more RAM, and there are really no downsides, so go 64-bit.

No, I don’t think they do… I read somewhere that they are trying to flush out the 32 bit. Well thanks, your input is decisive.

Read full topic

item.title: New Computer: 32 or 64 bit?
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

Mendorphins:

Hmm, one thing I just thought about. When the shops say it’s 64 bit - does that mean it’s 64 bit enabled or 64 bit installed?

it depends on what the store wants it to mean. u would think if it has a 64bit processor they would have a 64bit os, but my teacher bought a laptop from dell that has 64bit core i5 but came with 32-bit windows 7. u have to make sure it says 64-bit OS installed.

Read full topic

@Mendorphins wrote:

@M.dog: thank that person. The laptop is only 3GB RAM so I will get the 64 bit and install a 32 bit OS just like he said. That makes more sense to be honest

(3GB x64 running x86 is definitely faster than a 3GB x86 running x86, yes?) < if so, 64 bit it is.

And thanks for helping me make my decision fellow MPSC-ers.

item.title: New Computer: 32 or 64 bit?
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

I believe MITB will say that there’s no real reson not to use x64.

However, I have had some issues whilst using Java on a 64-bit machine. Even installing the 32-bit JDK/JVM didn’t help.

The thing with the 4GB limit is that the maximum value for an unsigned integer (2^32) is approximately 4 billion, which is maximum number of addresses that can be used. However, if you were to use the 64-bit architecture, the number becomes (2^64) which is approximately 16777216 terrabytes. So, in theory, using a 64-bit architecture would allow you to use 16777216 terrabytes of RAM before a limit was reached.

Read full topic

[quote=“ziplock, post:14, topic:405655”][quote author=krackkid link=topic=502649.msg3677840#msg3677840 date=1311351900]

Are you on 64 bit kracky?
[/quote]Yes and you can run 32 bit programs, But I installed photoshop(Totally legit I swear) and it said I had to be on a 32bit os, then would not run.

inb4 Daniel post

That’s strange. I had Photoshop when I was running my 64-bit Windows 7. o.o I had CS3 and CS5 and they both worked fine.[/quote]I got mine running, But I had to use a 64bit instead of a 32bit(cracked version) If that makes a difference.

item.title: New Computer: 32 or 64 bit?
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

Get the 64-bit as they are backwards-compatible. As previously stated, with a 64 bit architecture you can install either a 32-bit or 64-bit OS to your machine.

Read full topic

item.title: New Computer: 32 or 64 bit?
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

64-bit u can always install a 32-bit OS if u wanted. also u can always install 32-bit versions of the programs, so when u download the jdk and jre just get the 32-bit versions.

Read full topic

item.title: New Computer: 32 or 64 bit?
item.dc:creator: @Mendorphins Mendorphins
item.description:
@Mendorphins wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:9, topic:405655”][quote author=Mendorphins link=topic=502649.msg3677647#msg3677647 date=1311345508]

I have a 64bit laptop with the 64bit version of windows7. The only real thing I had to choose 32bit over 64bit so far was java. Other than this I see no performance issues.

What do you mean by that last bit.
[/quote]
Basically some java written programs fail on 64bit java, and I feel it is still buggy. I use 32bit because of the bugs.

Are you looking at a laptop or desktop? If laptop, and does it use ddr2 or ddr3 ram? I have a 2gb ddr2 laptop ram stick laying around if it would work.

Laptop. And DDR3 if I recall. You can’t mix and match?

No you can’t mix and match. Even if you could, but your slowest stick of ram will slow all other ram down to the same speed.[/quote]
Ok, this is vital right now then, because I’m getting the laptop for my OOP Java Open University course. What would you recommend?

If you say 64 bit if glitchy with Java and I’m doing a Java course, the logical thing is to get a 32 bit. the only problem is they don’t sell a 32 bit in my price range (ironic considering 64 bit is consider “better”).

Read full topic

I have a 64bit laptop with the 64bit version of windows7. The only real thing I had to choose 32bit over 64bit so far was java. Other than this I see no performance issues.
[/quote]
What do you mean by that last bit.[/quote]
Basically some java written programs fail on 64bit java, and I feel it is still buggy. I use 32bit because of the bugs.

[quote=“Mendorphins, post:8, topic:405655”][quote]
Are you looking at a laptop or desktop? If laptop, and does it use ddr2 or ddr3 ram? I have a 2gb ddr2 laptop ram stick laying around if it would work.
[/quote]
Laptop. And DDR3 if I recall. You can’t mix and match?[/quote]
No you can’t mix and match. Even if you could, but your slowest stick of ram will slow all other ram down to the same speed.

Read full topic
